solution: Using z = 1.96 and p = 0.5 for maximum variability, n = (1.96² × 0.25) / (0.01²) = 9604 (rounded up).

question: To estimate the proportion of residents favoring a nuclear power plant within 0.04 at 95% confidence, what sample size is required?
solution: Using z = 1.96 and p = 0.5, the sample size is n = (1.96² × 0.25) / (0.04²) = 601 (rounded up).

question: In a sample of 1000 males, 250 had a blood disorder. In 1000 females, 275 had it. Construct a 95% confidence interval for the difference in proportions.
A survey of 250 electrical engineers (80 women) and 175 chemical engineers (40 women) is conducted. Construct a 90% confidence interval for the difference in proportions of women in the two fields.
In a rat disease study, 120 of 500 uninoculated rats and 98 of 500 inoculated rats contracted the disease. Find a 90% confidence interval for the difference in proportions.
In a germination study, 10 of 20 broccoli seeds germinated at 5°C and 15 of 20 at 15°C. Find a 95% confidence interval for the difference in proportions.
In a 1990s poll, 274 of 1000 students chose baseball team A; in a newer poll, 240 of 760 students chose team A. Construct a 95% confidence interval for the difference in proportions.

In 1990, women were 33.7% of editorial staff at local TV stations. In 1994, they were 36.2%. From a group of 20 hires in each year, estimate the number of women and compute a 95% confidence interval for the difference.
An allergist wants to test whether at least 30% of the public is allergic to cheese products. Explain the possible type I and type II errors.
solution: A type I error would occur if we conclude that fewer than 30% are allergic when in fact 30% or more are. A type II error would occur if we conclude that at least 30% are allergic when in fact fewer than 30% are.

question: A sociologist is evaluating the effectiveness of a seat belt training course. Explain the hypotheses being tested when committing a type I and type II error.
solution: A type I error implies she concludes the training is ineffective when it is actually effective. A type II error implies she concludes the training is effective when it is actually ineffective.

question: A firm is being charged with discriminatory hiring. Identify the hypotheses in case of type I and type II errors by the jury.
solution: A type I error means the jury wrongly finds the firm guilty when it's not (the firm is not guilty). A type II error means the jury wrongly finds the firm not guilty when it is (the firm is guilty).

question: A manufacturer assumes the proportion of late raw material orders is 0.6. A sample of 10 shows 3 or fewer are late. Find type I and II error probabilities using binomial distribution for p = 0.6, 0.3, 0.4, 0.5.
Repeat Exercise 10.4 with a sample of 50 orders, critical region x ≤ 24. Use normal approximation. Find α and β for p = 0.3, 0.4, 0.5.
A town estimates 60% of adults are college graduates. In a sample of 15, we accept p = 0.6 if x is between 6 and 12. Compute α and β for p = 0.5 and p = 0.7.
Repeat Exercise 10.6 with a sample of 200 adults and fail-to-reject region 110 ≤ x ≤ 130. Use normal approximation. Find α and β for p = 0.5 and 0.7.
Test the claim that p = 0.4 in a sample of 7 arthritis patients. Fail to reject if 3 or more improve. Compute α and β for p = 0.4 and p = 0.3.
A dry cleaner claims their remover eliminates >70% of stains. 12 stains tested. Fail to reject H0 if fewer than 11 are removed. Compute α for p=0.7 and β for p=0.9.
Repeat Exercise 10.9 with 100 treated stains and rejection region x > 82. Compute α and β using normal approximation for p = 0.7 and p = 0.9.
Repeat Exercise 10.8 but with 70 patients and reject H0 if fewer than 24 receive relief. Compute α and β for p = 0.4 and p = 0.3.
A sample of 400 voters is polled about a gas tax. Conclude 60% are in favor if 220 < x < 260. Compute α and β for true p = 0.6 and p = 0.48.
In Exercise 10.12, change acceptance region to 215 < x < 266. Show how this affects α and β.
solution: α = 2P(Z < −2.60) = 0.0094. β = P(2.25 < Z < 7.36) = 1 − 0.9878 = 0.0122. So α is reduced while β increases.

question: A fishing line is claimed to have mean strength 15 kg. Test H0: μ = 15 vs H1: μ < 15 with σ = 0.5, n = 50, critical x̄ < 14.9. Compute α and β for μ = 14.8, 14.9.
Soft-drink machine has mean 200 ml, σ = 15. A sample of 9 is tested, and accept H0 if 191 < x̄ < 209. Find α and β for μ = 200 and μ = 215.
Repeat Exercise 10.15 with n = 25. Use the same acceptance region. Compute α and β for μ = 200 and μ = 215.
A cement's strength has μ = 5000, σ = 120. Reject H0 if x̄ < 4970 with n = 50. Compute α and β for μ = 4970 and 4960.
Plot the OC curve for the test in Exercise 10.15 using μ values from 184 to 216 in steps of 4. Describe its purpose.
solution: The OC curve shows the probability of not rejecting H0 for different μ values. For μ = 200, P = 0.9282. For μ further from 200, the probability of failing to reject H0 decreases.

question: Mice with average lifespan 32 months live 38 months on a special diet. Test if mean < 40 using P-value approach. n = 64, σ = 5.8.
Test if white cheddar popcorn bags weigh less than 5.5 oz. Sample: n = 64, x̄ = 5.23, s = 0.24. Use α = 0.05.
solution: z = (5.23−5.5)/(0.24/√64) = −9.00. P-value ≈ 0. Reject H0; bags weigh less than 5.5 oz.

question: A firm claims light bulbs last 800 hours. A sample of 30 gives x̄ = 788, σ = 40. Test μ = 800 vs μ ≠ 800 using P-value.
Men practicing TM meditate 8.5 hours/week (σ = 2.25, n = 225). Test if μ > 8 using P-value.
Test if mean content of lubricant containers is 10 L. Sample: 10.2, 9.7, 10.1, 10.3, 10.1, 9.8, 9.9, 10.4, 10.3, 9.8. α = 0.01.
The average height of freshman females has historically been 162.5 cm (σ = 6.9). A random sample of 50 has mean 165.2 cm. Test if average height has changed using a P-value.
solution: z = (165.2 − 162.5) / (6.9 / √50) = 2.77. P-value = 2P(Z > 2.77) = 0.0056. Reject H0; there has been a significant change in average height.

question: Test whether average annual car mileage exceeds 20,000 km. Sample: n = 100, mean = 23,500, σ = 3,900. Use a P-value.
Does a cereal have average sodium content above 220 mg? Sample: n = 20, mean = 244 mg, s = 24.5. α = 0.05.
solution: t = (244 − 220) / (24.5 / √20) = 4.38. Critical t = 1.729. Since 4.38 > 1.729, reject H0. Mean sodium content is greater than 220 mg.

question: Does running increase RMR in older women? Runners: n = 30, mean = 34%, sd = 10.5; Sedentary: n = 30, mean = 0%, sd = 10.2. Use a P-value.
solution: Pooled sd = 10.35. t = 34 / (10.35 √(1/30 + 1/30)) = 12.72. P-value ≈ 0. Reject H0; running significantly increases RMR.

question: Is absorbency higher for cotton than acetate? Cotton: n = 25, mean = 20, sd = 1.5; Acetate: n = 25, mean = 12, sd = 1.25. α = 0.05.
solution: Pooled sd ≈ 1.3807. t = (20 − 12) / (1.3807 √(2/25)) ≈ 20.48. P-value ≈ 0. Reject H0; cotton has significantly higher absorbency.

question: Is mean time to complete a standardized test < 35 minutes? Sample: n = 20, mean = 33.1, sd = 4.3. α = 0.05.
solution: t = (33.1 − 35) / (4.3 / √20) = −1.98. Critical t = −1.729. Since −1.98 < −1.729, reject H0; mean time is less than 35 minutes.

question: Test μ₁ = μ₂ for samples: n₁ = 25, x̄₁ = 81, σ₁ = 5.2; n₂ = 36, x̄₂ = 76, σ₂ = 3.4. Use P-value.
solution: z = (81 − 76) / √(5.2²/25 + 3.4²/36) = 4.22. P-value ≈ 0. Reject H0; means differ significantly.

question: Does type A thread exceed type B by ≥12 kg? A: n = 50, mean = 86.7, sd = 6.28; B: n = 50, mean = 77.8, sd = 5.61. α = 0.05.
solution: z = ((86.7 − 77.8) − 12) / √(6.28²/50 + 5.61²/50) = −2.60. Since z < 1.645, fail to reject H0; difference is not ≥12 kg.

question: Is mean salary for research professors $2,000 higher than others? Research: n = 200, mean = 70,750, sd = 6,000; Others: n = 200, mean = 65,200, sd = 5,000. α = 0.01.
Is mean reaction velocity increased >0.5 with substrate increase? Group1: n = 15, mean = 7.5, sd = 1.5; Group2: n = 12, mean = 8.8, sd = 1.2. α = 0.01.
Does lab course raise physics grades ≥8 points? With lab: n = 11, mean = 85, sd = 4.7; Without lab: n = 17, mean = 79, sd = 6.1. Use P-value.
solution: Pooled variance ≈ 31.395. t = (85 − 79 − 8) / (√31.395 √(1/11 + 1/17)) = −0.92. P-value between 0.15 and 0.20. Do not reject H0.

question: Is serum effective against leukemia? Treatment: n = 5, mean = 2.86; Control: n = 4, mean = 2.075. Use pooled sd and t-test. α = 0.05.
Is there a difference in tire wear between brands A and B? A: n = 12, mean = 37900, sd = 5100; B: n = 12, mean = 39800, sd = 5900. Use P-value.
Do VW mini-trucks exceed Toyota by 4 km/L? VW: n = 12, mean = 16; Toyota: n = 10, mean = 11. Use t-test at α = 0.10.
Does mouse diet increase lifespan by 8 months? Normal: n = 10, mean = 32.1, sd = 3.2; Restricted: n = 15, mean = 37.6, sd = 2.8. α = 0.05.
solution: Pooled variance ≈ 31.395, t = (37.6 − 32.1 − 8) / (√31.395 √(1/10 + 1/15)) = −0.92. P-value between 0.15 and 0.20. Do not reject H0.

question: Compare film lengths from 2 companies. Company 1: 5 times; Company 2: 7 times. Test if company 2 exceeds by 10 mins. α = 0.10.
solution: t = (mean2 − mean1 − 10) / SE. t = −2.07. Critical t ≈ −1.734. Reject H0.

question: Compare plasma ascorbic acid in smokers vs nonsmokers (32 total, normal distribution, unequal variance). Use P-value.
solution: t = −0.42. P-value between 0.6 and 0.8. Fail to reject H0; no significant difference.

question: Compare density of organisms at two stations in Cedar Run. Use two-sample t-test with unequal variance. α = 0.05.
solution: t = 2.76, df = 19, critical t = 2.093. Reject H0; densities are significantly different.

question: Test difference in iron content from X-ray and chemical analysis on 5 samples. Use paired t-test. α = 0.05.
solution: t = −1.58, df = 4, critical t = ±2.776. Fail to reject H0; no significant difference.

question: Does fatigue affect movement accuracy? Use paired data for 15 subjects. α = 0.05.
solution: t = −2.53, P-value between 0.01 and 0.015. Reject H0; fatigue significantly affects performance.

question: Is there a difference in sorbic acid residuals before and after 60 days of storage? n = 8. α = 0.05.
solution: t = 2.67, df = 7, critical t = 2.365. Reject H0; storage affects residuals.

question: Do radial tires improve fuel economy vs belted tires? Paired data, n = 12. α = 0.05.
solution: t = 2.48, df = 11, P-value between 0.015 and 0.02. Reject H0; radial tires improve fuel economy.

question: Test if diet reduces weight by 4.5 kg on average using paired t-test. d̄ = 3.557, sd = 2.776, n = 7.
solution: t = (3.557 − 4.5) / (2.776 / √7) = −0.896. P-value between 0.2 and 0.3. Do not reject H0.

question: How large should n be in Exercise 10.20 to achieve 90% power when true mean = 5.20? σ = 0.24.
solution: Using power and effect size: n = ((1.645 + 1.282) × 0.24 / 0.3)² = 5.48 → round up to 6.

question: Determine sample size to achieve β = 0.1 when true mean is 35.9 (vs H0: μ = 40). σ = 5.8.
Determine the sample size to achieve 95% power when the true average height differs from 162.5 cm by 3.1 cm. Use α = 0.02 and σ = 6.9.
solution: Using the formula for power and normal distribution: n = ((1.645 + 2.33)² × 6.9²) / 3.1² = 78.28, so sample size needed is 79.

question: Find the sample size needed in Exercise 10.31 to achieve 95% power if the true difference between threads A and B is 8 kg.
solution: n = ((1.645 + 1.645)² × (6.28² + 5.61²)) / 8² = 11.99, so required sample size is 12.

question: Determine the sample size for Exercise 10.22 if the power is to be 0.8 when the true mean exceeds the hypothesized value by 1.2σ. Use α = 0.05.
For a t-test of H0: μ = 14 at α = 0.05, find sample size to ensure probability of falsely failing to reject H0 is 0.1 when true mean differs from 14 by 0.5. σ = 1.25.
solution: Δ = 0.5 / 1.25 = 0.4. Using Table A.8, required sample size is 68.

question: Does knife temperature affect wound strength? Paired data from 8 dogs using hot and cold incisions.
solution: Paired t-test gives t = 0.99, P-value between 0.3 and 0.4. Fail to reject H0; no significant difference in strength.

question: Does exposure to CO increase breathing frequency? Paired data from 9 subjects. α = 0.05.
solution: t = 2.4 with df = 8. P-value between 0.02 and 0.025. Reject H0; breathing frequency significantly increases in CO environment.

question: A marketing expert claims 40% prefer lasagna. In a sample of 20, 9 choose lasagna. Test at α = 0.05.
solution: P-value = P(X ≥ 9 | p = 0.4) = 0.4044. Since P-value > 0.05, do not reject H0.

question: Test if support for capital punishment exceeds 40%. In a sample of 15, 8 favor it. α = 0.05.
solution: P-value = P(X ≥ 8 | p = 0.4) = 0.2131. Since P-value > 0.05, fail to reject H0.

question: Is new missile radar system no better than 0.8 accuracy? In 300 trials, 250 kills occurred. α = 0.04.
Test if less than 60% of voters favor annexation. In sample of 200, 110 support. α = 0.05.
Test if fewer than 20% of homes are heated by oil. In 1000 homes, 136 use oil.
Is more than 25% of students riding bicycles? In 90 students, 28 do. α = 0.05.
Compare proportions cured with vs. without new medicine. 29/120 treated vs. 56/280 control. α = 0.05.
solution: z = 0.93, P-value = 0.1762. Fail to reject H0; no significant evidence of medicine effectiveness.

question: Test if tumor rate exceeds 25% in rats on coffee bean diet. 16/48 develop tumors. α = 0.05.
solution: z = 1.333. P-value = 0.0918. Fail to reject H0.

question: Do urban and suburban residents differ in support for nuclear plant? Urban: 63/100; Suburban: 59/125.
solution: z = 2.36. P-value = 0.0182. Reject H0; proportions differ significantly.

question: Do more wives married <2 yrs plan to have children than those married 5 yrs? 240/300 vs. 288/400.
solution: z = 2.44. P-value = 0.0073. Reject H0; recently married wives are more likely to plan children.

question: Compare breast cancer rates: Urban 20/200 vs. Rural 10/150. α = 0.05.
solution: z = 1.10. P-value = 0.1357. Fail to reject H0.

question: Students are surveyed: do ≥25% exercise >2 hours/week? Sample of 50.
solution: Hypothetical setup; final conclusion depends on actual survey data. Compute proportion and compare against null p = 0.25 using binomial or z-test.

question: Test if variance of lubricant containers is ≠ 0.03. Sample of 10 containers: s² = 0.24585².
solution: χ² = 9 × 0.24585² / 0.03 = 18.13. P-value between 0.05 and 0.10. Fail to reject H0.

question: Test if σ < 6 for test times of seniors. Sample: n = 20, s = 4.51. α = 0.05.
solution: χ² = 19 × 4.51² / 36 = 10.74. P-value between 0.05 and 0.1. Fail to reject H0.

question: Test if variance of aflotoxins is ≠ 4.2 ppm. Sample: n = 64, s² = 4.25.
solution: χ² = 63 × 4.25² / 4.2 = 63.75. P-value ≈ 0.8898. Fail to reject H0.

question: Test if σ > 1.40 for sanitation worker donations. Sample: n = 12, s = 1.75. α = 0.01.
solution: χ² = 11 × 1.75² / 1.4² = 17.19. P-value between 0.1 and 0.2. Fail to reject H0.

question: Test if soda machine is out of control (σ² > 1.15). Sample: n = 25, s² = 2.03. α = 0.05.
solution: χ² = 24 × 2.03 / 1.15 = 42.37. P-value between 0.01 and 0.02. Reject H0.

question: Test if σ = 10.0 using z-approximation. Sample: s = 11.9, n = 200.
Test if variance of diesel distance < 6.25. Sample: n = 72, s² = 4.41. α = 0.05.
Compare time variances for men vs. women assembling products. Men: n = 11, s = 6.1; Women: n = 14, s = 5.3.
solution: F = (6.1)² / (5.3)² = 1.33. P-value = 0.3095. Fail to reject H0.

question: Using data from Exercise 10.41, test if the variances of organism densities at two stations differ. α = 0.05.
solution: F = (7874.329)² / (2479.503)² = 10.09. Since F > critical value, P-value = 0.0004. Reject H0; variances differ significantly.

question: Use Exercise 10.39 to test if the variances of film running times from two companies differ. α = 0.05.
solution: F = 78.800 / 913.333 = 0.086. P-value = 0.0328. Reject H0; variances are significantly different.

question: Compare variability of two sulfur monoxide measuring instruments. A and B have equal sample sizes of 9.
solution: F = 0.0125 / 0.0108 = 1.15. P-value = 0.848. Fail to reject H0; instruments have similar variability.

question: Compare alcohol content variability from two soy sauce production lines. Each has 8 measurements.
solution: F = (0.0553)² / (0.0125)² = 19.67. P-value = 0.0008. Reject H0; production line 1 has higher variability.

question: Test if 1980 and 1990 model cars differ in hydrocarbon emission variances. n = 20 each.
solution: F = (291.0667)² / (119.3946)² = 5.54. P-value = 0.0004. Reject H0; variances differ.

question: Test if a nut-mixing machine maintains the ratio 5:2:2:1 (total 500 nuts). α = 0.05.
solution: χ² = 10.14, df = 3, critical value = 7.815. Since 10.14 > 7.815, reject H0; nuts are not mixed in correct ratio.

question: Test if grade distribution A–F is uniform. Frequencies: 14, 18, 32, 20, 16. α = 0.05.
solution: χ² = 10.0, df = 4, critical value = 9.488. Since 10.0 > 9.488, reject H0; grade distribution is not uniform.

question: Is a die balanced? Frequencies of 6 faces in 180 tosses: [28, 36, 36, 30, 27, 23]. α = 0.01.
solution: χ² = 4.47, df = 5, critical value = 15.086. Since 4.47 < 15.086, fail to reject H0; die is balanced.

question: Test if marble selection follows hypergeometric h(x; 8,3,5). Observed: [1, 31, 55, 25]. α = 0.05.
solution: χ² = 1.67, df = 2, critical value = 5.991. Since 1.67 < 5.991, fail to reject H0; data fits the distribution.

question: Test if number of tosses until first head follows geometric distribution with p = 0.5. α = 0.05.
solution: χ² = 3.125, df = 5, critical value = 11.070. Since 3.125 < 11.070, fail to reject H0.

question: Test goodness-of-fit of grade distribution to normal N(65, 21). Observed and expected provided. α = 0.05.
solution: χ² = 12.78, df = 6, critical value = 12.592. Since 12.78 > 12.592, reject H0; data not normally distributed.

question: Test if nicotine levels follow N(1.8, 0.4) using equal-probability bins. n = 30, α = 0.01.
solution: χ² = 40.4, df = 6, critical value = 15.086. Since 40.4 > 15.086, reject H0; distribution differs from normal.

question: Test independence between smoking habits and hypertension. Observed frequencies provided. α = 0.05.
solution: χ² = 14.60, df = 2, critical value = 5.991. Since 14.60 > 5.991, reject H0; variables are not independent.

question: Test if time spent watching TV is independent of gender. Sample of 90. α = 0.01.
solution: χ² = 5.4, df = 1, critical value = 6.635. Since 5.4 < 6.635, fail to reject H0; variables are independent.

question: Test if family size is independent of father's education. Data from 200 retired men. α = 0.05.
solution: χ² = 7.54, df = 4, critical value = 9.488. Since 7.54 < 9.488, fail to reject H0; variables are independent.

question: Test if crime type occurrence is independent of city district. Frequencies provided. α = 0.01.
solution: χ² = 124.59, df = 9, critical value = 21.666. Since 124.59 > 21.666, reject H0; crime type is district-dependent.

question: Are widowhood survival times independent of gender? Data from 100 widows and 100 widowers. α = 0.05.
solution: χ² = 5.96, df = 2, critical value = 5.991. Since 5.96 < 5.991, fail to reject H0; proportions are equal.

question: Test if standard-of-living perception changed over 4 time periods. 1000 household responses. α = 0.05.
solution: χ² = 5.92, df = 6, critical value = 12.592. Since 5.92 < 12.592, fail to reject H0; proportions did not change.

question: Are 3 cough remedies equally effective? Each tested on 50 students. α = 0.05.
solution: χ² = 3.81, df = 4, critical value = 9.488. Since 3.81 < 9.488, fail to reject H0; remedies are equally effective.

question: Test if prayer attitudes are homogeneous across 4 counties. Data from 550 parents. α = 0.01.
solution: χ² = 31.17, df = 6, critical value = 16.812. Since 31.17 > 16.812, reject H0; attitudes differ across counties.

question: Test if school busing attitudes are the same across Indiana, Kentucky, and Ohio. α = 0.05.
solution: χ² = 12.56, df = 4, critical value = 9.488. Since 12.56 > 9.488, reject H0; proportions differ among states.

question: Test if voter sentiment differs between Richmond and Norfolk. α = 0.05.
solution: χ² = 1.84, df = 2, critical value = 5.991. Since 1.84 < 5.991, fail to reject H0; sentiments are the same.

question: Test if soap opera viewing rates differ in Denver, Phoenix, and Rochester. α = 0.05.
solution: χ² = 1.39, df = 2, critical value = 5.991. Since 1.39 < 5.991, fail to reject H0; no difference in proportions.

question: Write H0 and H1 for the claim: Mean snowfall at Lake George in Feb. is 21.8 cm.
solution: H0: μ = 21.8; H1: μ ≠ 21.8. Critical region is two-tailed.

question: Write H0 and H1 for: No more than 20% of faculty donate to giving fund.
solution: H0: p = 0.2; H1: p > 0.2. Critical region is right-tailed.

question: Write H0 and H1 for: Average school distance for kids in St. Louis is 6.2 km.
solution: H0: μ = 6.2; H1: μ > 6.2. Critical region is right-tailed.

question: Write H0 and H1 for: At least 70% of next year's cars are compact/subcompact.
solution: H0: p = 0.7; H1: p < 0.7. Critical region is left-tailed.

question: Write H0 and H1 for: 58% of voters support the incumbent.
solution: H0: p = 0.58; H1: p ≠ 0.58. Critical region is two-tailed.

question: Write H0 and H1 for the claim: Average rib-eye steak weighs at least 340 grams.
solution: H0: μ = 340; H1: μ < 340. Critical region is left-tailed.

question: In a sample of 100 males, 31 have a blood disorder; 24 of 100 females have it. Test if male proportion is significantly higher. α = 0.01.
72 of 300 Italians and 70 of 400 Americans prefer white champagne. Test if more Italians prefer it. α = 0.05.
solution: p̂1 = 0.24, p̂2 = 0.175, p̂ = 0.203. z = 2.12. P-value = 0.017. Reject H0; more Italians prefer white champagne.

question: Oxygen consumption in mL/kg/min is measured in 9 subjects with and without CO. d̄ = 1.58, sd = 3.07. Use paired t-test.
solution: t = 1.58 / (3.07 / √9) = 1.55. P-value > 0.05. Fail to reject H0; data is insufficient to conclude difference.

question: Compare computer task completion times with and without facilitation tools. n = 5 each, x̄₁ = 165, s₁ = 6.442; x̄₂ = 139.8, s₂ = 12.617.
solution: sp = 10.02. t = (165 − 139.8) / (10.02 √(1/5 + 1/5)) = 3.98. P-value < 0.005. Reject H0; facilitation tools improve speed.

question: Write H0 and H1 for: At most, 20% of next year's wheat crop will be exported.
solution: H0: p = 0.2; H1: p > 0.2. Critical region is right-tailed.

question: Write H0 and H1 for: Average American homemaker drinks 3 cups of coffee per day.
solution: H0: μ = 3; H1: μ ≠ 3. Critical region is two-tailed.

question: Write H0 and H1 for: Proportion of social science graduates is at least 0.15.
solution: H0: p = 0.15; H1: p < 0.15. Critical region is left-tailed.

question: Write H0 and H1 for: Average donation to the Lung Association is no more than $10.
solution: H0: μ = 10; H1: μ > 10. Critical region is right-tailed.

question: Write H0 and H1 for: Average commute in suburban Richmond is 15 km.
solution: H0: μ = 15; H1: μ ≠ 15. Critical region is two-tailed.

question: A can of 500 mixed nuts from 3 distributors has 345, 313, and 359 peanuts respectively. Test if peanut proportions differ. α = 0.01.
solution: χ² = 10.19, df = 2, critical value = 9.210. Since 10.19 > 9.210, reject H0; peanut proportions differ.

question: Test if support for Bibles in schools is equal across MD, VA, GA, AL. 100 parents per state. α = 0.01.
solution: χ² = 8.84, df = 3, critical value = 11.345. Since 8.84 < 11.345, fail to reject H0.

question: Test if surgery significantly changes WBC leukograms in foals. Paired data from 6 foals. d̄ = −2.905, sd = 3.3557.
solution: t = −2.12, df = 5. P-value between 0.05 and 0.10. Fail to reject H0; no significant change in WBC.

question: Cholesterol levels from treatment group (n = 15) and control (n = 18). Test if treatment reduced average cholesterol. α = 0.05.
solution: t = −1.23, df = 31. P-value > 0.10. Fail to reject H0; no significant reduction due to treatment.

question: Compare steel rods from companies A and B. A: n = 10, mean = 7.84; B: n = 10, mean = 10.02. Test for difference.
solution: t = −5.90, df = 13. P-value < 0.0005. Reject H0; steel rods are significantly different.

question: Compare wastewater amounts from Plant A (low income) and B (high income). n = 10 each. A: mean = 21.5; B: mean = 28.3.
solution: t = −2.71, P-value between 0.005 and 0.0075. Reject H0; Plant B treats more wastewater.

question: Compare software defect rates in US vs. Japan. US: n = 16, mean = 48.1875; Japan: mean = 43.75. Test difference.
solution: t = 2.59, df = 30. P-value between 0.01 and 0.015. Reject H0; significant difference in defects.

question: Perform an ANOVA at the 0.01 significance level to determine if the burn times differ among the four fabric treatments.
solution: The ANOVA yielded an F-statistic of 13.50 and a P-value < 0.0001. Since this is less than 0.01, the treatment means differ significantly.

question: Using single-degree-of-freedom contrasts at α = 0.01, compare burn times between treatments 1 and 2, and between treatments 3 and 4.
solution: The contrast between treatments 1 and 2 had an F-value of 29.35 with P < 0.0001, indicating a significant difference. The contrast between treatments 3 and 4 had an F-value of 3.59 with P = 0.0648, indicating no significant difference.

question: Perform an ANOVA at the 0.05 level to test if perspiration nitrogen loss differs across three protein levels (29g, 54g, 84g).
solution: The F-statistic was 5.15 with a P-value of 0.0323. Since this is less than 0.05, we reject the null hypothesis. There is a significant difference in perspiration nitrogen loss across protein levels.

question: Use Tukey’s test to determine which protein level(s) differ in mean perspiration nitrogen loss.
solution: The contrast comparing 29g vs. the average of 54g and 84g produced an F-value of 9.86 with P = 0.0119. This indicates that the 29g protein group is significantly different from the higher protein groups.

question: Using Tukey’s test, determine which headache tablet brands from Exercise 13.2 differ significantly in mean relief hours.
solution: Tukey’s test with a critical difference of 3.27 showed that Tablet D had the lowest mean (2.98), significantly lower than Tablets A (5.44), B (7.90), and E (6.96). Tablet B had the highest mean.

question: Perform an ANOVA at the 0.05 level to determine whether blends of material result in different yield reductions in a chemical process.
solution: The ANOVA yielded an F-statistic of 7.10 with a P-value of 0.0121. Since this is less than 0.05, we reject the null hypothesis. The blends differ in mean yield reductions.

question: Use Duncan’s multiple-range test to identify which blends differ significantly.
solution: Duncan’s test identified Blend 4 (mean 31.90) as significantly different from Blend 3 (mean 23.23). Blends 1 and 2 (means 25.93 and 26.17) were intermediate.

question: Use Tukey’s test to determine which blends from Exercise 13.16 differ significantly.
solution: Tukey’s test with a critical difference of 6.20 showed that Blend 4 (31.90) was significantly different from Blend 3 (23.23), but not necessarily from Blends 1 or 2.

question: Perform an ANOVA to determine whether the average species count differs among five different sampling procedures.
solution: The F-statistic was 9.01 with a P-value of 0.0006, indicating significant differences in species counts among the procedures.

question: Use Tukey’s test to identify which sampling procedures differ in mean species count.
solution: Tukey’s test found significant differences between low-performing methods (Kicknet: 12.5) and high-performing methods (Depletion: 64.25).

question: The pressure in a torsion spring was measured for several angle settings. Perform a one-way ANOVA to determine if the angle setting significantly affects the pressure. Use a 0.05 significance level.
solution: The F-statistic was 21.40 with a P-value < 0.0001. Since this is much less than 0.05, we reject the null hypothesis. The angle setting significantly affects the spring pressure.

question: Batteries were tested at five different temperatures to determine if temperature affects battery life. Use an ANOVA to analyze the data.
solution: The F-statistic was 70.27 with a P-value < 0.0001. This provides strong evidence to reject the null hypothesis. Battery life significantly differs based on the activation temperature.

question: Tensile strength of wires from nine cables was tested. Use ANOVA to determine whether mean wire strength differs across cables.
solution: The F-statistic was 9.07 with a P-value < 0.0001. The null hypothesis is rejected. The wire strengths differ significantly across cables.

question: Use Duncan’s test to identify significant paired differences for aggregate absorption data.
solution: Duncan’s test showed that aggregate 4 had a significantly lower absorption rate than the others.

question: Use Duncan’s test to compare mean sorption rates of solvents in Exercise 13.6.
solution: Duncan’s test showed that Esters had significantly lower sorption rates compared to Aromatics and Chloroalkanes.

question: A chemical was applied at four concentrations and a control to test plant growth. Use Dunnett’s test at α = 0.05 to compare each treatment to the control.
solution: Dunnett’s test showed that concentrations 1 and 2 were significantly different from the control. Concentrations 3 and 4 were not.

question: A study measured return on equity at four levels of financial leverage. Use ANOVA at the 0.05 level to determine if leverage affects returns.
solution: The F-statistic was 5.34 with a P-value of 0.0073. The null hypothesis is rejected, indicating significant differences in return on equity based on leverage.

question: Use Dunnett’s test at α = 0.01 to determine whether low, medium, or high financial leverage results in significantly higher returns than control.
solution: Dunnett’s test showed that both medium and high financial leverage produced significantly higher returns than the control. Low leverage did not.

question: An experiment tested the effect of four fertilizers on bean yield using a randomized complete block design. Use ANOVA at the 0.05 level to evaluate the fertilizer effect.
solution: The F-statistic was 6.11 with a P-value of 0.0296. We reject the null hypothesis. Fertilizer type has a significant effect on bean yield.

question: Three potato varieties were tested at four locations. Use a randomized complete block ANOVA at the 0.05 level to determine if there is a difference in yield.
solution: The F-statistic was 1.74 with a P-value of 0.2535. Since this is greater than 0.05, we fail to reject the null hypothesis. No significant differences among potato varieties were found.

question: Three brands of strawberry jam were analyzed for additive content by five analysts. Use a randomized complete block ANOVA at the 0.05 level.
solution: The F-statistic was 5.99 with a P-value of 0.0257. The null hypothesis is rejected. The average additive content differs among brands. Jam A had the lowest mean.

question: Five students received grades in math, English, French, and biology. Test whether the subjects differ in difficulty using a one-way ANOVA.
solution: The F-statistic was 0.15 with a P-value of 0.9267. We fail to reject the null hypothesis. No significant differences in difficulty among the courses were found.

question: Mercury concentration in periphyton was measured at six stations on six days. Test if average concentration differs by station. Use P-value.
solution: The F-statistic was 26.14 with a P-value < 0.0001. We reject the null hypothesis. Mercury levels vary significantly across stations.

question: Monthly chlorophyll a concentrations were recorded at three stations over 12 months. Perform ANOVA at α = 0.05 to see if station affects mean concentration.
solution: The F-statistic was 0.15 with a P-value of 0.8620. We fail to reject the null hypothesis. There is no evidence that chlorophyll a levels differ by station.

question: Six subjects were tested for treadmill exhaustion time under three different diets. Use randomized block ANOVA to determine if diets differ significantly.
solution: The F-statistic was 11.86 with a P-value of 0.0023. We reject the null hypothesis. There are significant differences among the diets in time to exhaustion.

question: Urine samples were analyzed for arsenic by three methods. Perform ANOVA at α = 0.05 to see if methods differ significantly.
solution: The F-statistic was 3.00 with a P-value of 0.1250. We fail to reject the null hypothesis. There is no significant difference among the methods.

question: Five treatments were applied to six orchard locations to test tree growth. Perform ANOVA to determine if treatments differ significantly.
solution: The F-statistic was 0.58 with a P-value of 0.6821. We fail to reject the null hypothesis. There are no significant differences among treatments.

question: Ten subjects followed one of three weight loss treatments. Use ANOVA at α = 0.01 to determine if weight loss differs across treatments.
solution: The F-statistic was 8.60 with a P-value of 0.0024. We reject the null hypothesis. The therapist-controlled program had the greatest weight loss effect.

question: Three dye concentrations were tested at two plants for fabric color density. Perform ANOVA considering plants as blocks.
solution: The F-statistic for dye levels was 122.37 with P < 0.0001. There are significant differences in color density among dye levels.

question: Flaws in coated copper wire were counted under three materials. Perform ANOVA after variance-stabilizing transformation.
solution: After applying a square root transformation, the F-statistic was 16.20 with a P-value < 0.0001. The materials differ significantly in flaw counts.

question: Four labs performed HIV control tests. Write a model for analyzing variation.
solution: The appropriate model is yᵢⱼ = μ + αᵢ + εᵢⱼ, where αᵢ ~ N(0, σ²ₐ), representing lab variance as a random effect.

question: Estimate laboratory variance and within-lab variance for HIV control data.
solution: The estimated total variance was 0.02056 and within-lab variance was 0.01791. The between-lab variance estimate was essentially zero (σ²ₐ = 0).

question: Four treatments were compared in five blocks. Use random effects ANOVA at α = 0.05 to test for differences.
solution: The F-statistic was 3.33 with a P-value of 0.0565. The result is marginally non-significant at α = 0.05.

question: Estimate treatment and block variance components from Exercise 13.38.
solution: Treatment variance estimate σ²ₐ = 1.084, block variance σ²ᵦ = 2.248. Error variance was 2.328.

question: Four operators were tested for machine output. Perform random effects ANOVA at α = 0.05.
solution: The F-statistic was 14.91 with a P-value of 0.0002. The operator effect is significant. We reject the null hypothesis.

question: Perform Bartlett’s test at α = 0.1 on the aggregate data from Example 13.1 to determine if variances differ significantly.
solution: The Bartlett’s statistic was 0.8254. Since it is greater than the critical value, we fail to reject the null hypothesis. The variances are not significantly different.

question: Four catalysts, including a control, were tested for yield. Use Dunnett’s test at α = 0.01 to determine if any catalyst gives significantly higher yield than the control.
solution: All three catalysts showed significantly higher mean yields than the control. Dunnett’s test statistic exceeded the critical value in each case.

question: Use Bartlett’s test at α = 0.05 to determine if variances differ among the four laboratories from Review Exercise 13.45.
solution: The Bartlett’s test statistic was 0.7678, which is greater than the critical value of 0.5850. We fail to reject the null hypothesis. Variances are not significantly different.

question: Perform an ANOVA to determine if there are significant differences in means among the four laboratories in Exercise 13.45.
solution: The F-statistic was 13.33 with a P-value of 0.0001. We reject the null hypothesis. The mean results differ significantly across laboratories.

question: Four diets were tested for their effect on percent dry matter digested by sheep. Perform a randomized block ANOVA at α = 0.05.
solution: The F-statistic was 38.65 with a P-value < 0.0001. We reject the null hypothesis. There is a significant difference among the diets.

question: Use Dunnett’s test at α = 0.05 to compare three diets with the control diet in Exercise 13.46.
solution: Dunnett’s test showed that both ammonia-treated and urea-treated diets were significantly different from the control. The urea-at-feeding diet was not significantly different.

question: Three diets were tested on pregnant rats for residual dietary zinc levels. Use one-way ANOVA at α = 0.05 to test for differences.
solution: The F-statistic was 9.33 with a P-value of 0.0036. We reject the null hypothesis. Residual zinc levels differ significantly among diets.

question: Three types of paint were tested for wearing time. Perform ANOVA and state whether wearing quality differs significantly. Use a P-value.
solution: The F-statistic was 5.08 with a P-value of 0.0207. We reject the null hypothesis. There is a significant difference in wearing quality among the paints.

question: Use Tukey’s test to determine which paint types differ in average wearing quality.
solution: Tukey’s test showed that Paint Type 1 (mean 197.83) was significantly different from Type 2 (450.50) and Type 3 (419.50), while Types 2 and 3 were not significantly different from each other.

question: Why were stamping machines used as blocks in the gasket production study?
solution: Stamping machines might contribute to variability in output. Blocking removes machine-related variation to better detect differences in material performance.

question: Plot the six means from the gasket production study by machine and material. Identify trends.
solution: The plot showed that Cork had the highest mean output, followed by Plastic, then Rubber. Machine A consistently had higher means than Machine B.

question: Is there a single best material in the gasket production experiment?
solution: Yes. Cork was the best-performing material based on highest average number of gaskets produced.

question: Is there a material-machine interaction effect in the gasket production experiment?
solution: Yes. There is an interaction: Cork and Plastic perform better on Machine A, while Rubber performs better on Machine B.

question: Why were multiple car models used in the gas mileage study comparing gasoline brands?
solution: To generalize results and account for model-based variation in gas mileage, multiple models were needed as blocks.

question: Did gasoline brand affect gas mileage? Use the ANOVA output.
solution: The F-statistic for brand was 9.21 with a P-value of 0.0148. We reject the null hypothesis. Brand significantly affects gas mileage.

question: Which brand of gasoline should be chosen based on Duncan’s test?
solution: Brand C had the highest mean and was significantly better than Brand A. Brand C is the recommended choice.

question: Were mean ozone levels significantly different across four locations? Use a P-value.
solution: The F-statistic was 13.80 with a P-value of 0.0001. We reject the null hypothesis. Ozone levels differ across locations.

question: Which locations had significantly different ozone levels according to Tukey’s test?
solution: Location 2 had significantly higher ozone levels than the other three. Locations 1, 3, and 4 had similar, lower levels.

question: Show that the mean square error in one-way ANOVA is an unbiased estimate of σ².
solution: By computing E(SSE), we find that E[MSE] = E[SSE / (k(n−1))] = σ², proving it's an unbiased estimator.

question: Prove Theorem 13.2 related to expected value of SSA in one-way ANOVA.
solution: Using expected values of sample means and properties of the ANOVA model, E(SSA) = (k−1)σ² + n∑α²ᵢ.

question: Show that the computing formula for SSB in randomized complete block design matches the theorem.
solution: Using algebraic identities and summation notation, the computing formula for SSB was shown to equal ∑T²ⱼ/k − T².. / bk.

question: Show that E(SSB) = (b−1)σ² + k∑β²ⱼ in randomized block design.
solution: Using the ANOVA model and variance properties, the expected value of SSB was shown to be (b−1)σ² + k∑β²ⱼ.

question: Why is the experiment in Exercise 13.56 a randomized complete block design?
solution: Each individual is treated as a block to control for variation in throwing ability, while the ball type is the treatment.

question: What should be included in the results of the ball-throwing experiment?
solution: The results should include a description of the design, ANOVA table with P-value, multiple comparisons if needed, and graphical summaries.

question: An experiment was conducted to study the effects of temperature and type of oven on the life of a particular component. Four types of ovens and three temperature levels were used. Using a 0.05 level of significance, test whether (a) different temperatures have no effect on the life of the component; (b) different ovens have no effect; (c) temperature and oven type do not interact.
solution: The ANOVA test results show that the F-statistic for temperature is 8.13, for oven is 5.18, and for interaction is 1.63. With corresponding critical values of 3.00, 3.89, and 3.49 respectively, we reject the null hypotheses for temperature and oven effects, but we do not reject the null for interaction. This indicates both temperature and oven type significantly affect component life, but there is no interaction between the two.

question: A study was conducted to test vitamin C retention in reconstituted frozen orange juice from three brands stored over three time periods. At a 0.05 significance level, test whether (a) there is no difference among the brands; (b) there is no difference among the storage times; (c) brands and storage times do not interact.
solution: The ANOVA table shows F-values of 1.74 for brands, 12.04 for time, and 0.46 for interaction. At the 0.05 significance level, only the time effect is significant. Thus, we conclude that storage time significantly affects vitamin C content, but brand and interaction effects are not significant.

question: Three strains of rats were tested under two environmental conditions for maze performance. Using a 0.01 level of significance, test whether (a) environment affects error scores; (b) strain affects error scores; (c) environment and strain interact.
solution: The F-values for environment and strain are 14.81 and 9.04, respectively, while the interaction F-value is 0.61. At α = 0.01, both main effects are significant, but the interaction is not. Therefore, environment and strain both influence error scores, but their interaction does not.

question: In a corrosion fatigue study, three humidity levels and three surface coatings were tested. At a 0.01 significance level, test for (a) coating effect, (b) humidity effect, and (c) interaction effect. Also use Duncan’s test to compare humidity levels.
solution: All main effects are significant with F-values of 6.87 for coating and 4.57 for humidity. The interaction F-value is 2.44, below the threshold, so interaction is not significant. Duncan’s test shows medium humidity differs significantly from both low and high humidity in terms of corrosion fatigue.

question: Five muscles were tested on three subjects during a tennis flat serve to determine which muscles need conditioning. Use a 0.01 significance level to test whether (a) subject affects measurements, (b) muscle type affects measurements, (c) subject and muscle interact.
solution: All three effects—subject (F = 34.40), muscle (F = 26.95), and interaction (F = 20.30)—are significant at the 0.01 level. Thus, each subject and each muscle type affects electromyographic readings, and there is significant interaction between subjects and muscles.

question: An experiment tested whether additives affect rubber product adhesiveness across four temperatures. Perform ANOVA to test for main and interaction effects.
solution: All three effects are statistically significant. Additive F = 22.29 (p < 0.0001), Temperature F = 3.41 (p = 0.0338), and Interaction F = 7.58 (p = 0.0010). Therefore, additive and temperature both affect adhesiveness and their interaction is also significant.

question: An experiment on polymer extraction tested four temperatures and five catalyst levels. Perform ANOVA to assess main and interaction effects.
solution: Temperature (F = 10.85) and catalyst (F = 46.63) are both highly significant (p < 0.0002). The interaction (F = 2.06) has a p-value of 0.0745, which is not significant at the 0.05 level. Thus, only the main effects are significant.

question: An experiment with two nickel levels and three pH levels tested their effects on material thickness. Perform ANOVA and interpret results.
solution: Nickel (F = 44.52) and pH (F = 4.71) are significant, but their interaction (F = 0.48) is not. Thus, both factors individually influence thickness, but they do not interact.

question: A two-factor experiment tested tool geometry and cutting speed for their effects on machine tool life. Perform ANOVA and interpret interaction and main effects.
solution: Interaction is significant (F = 21.14, p = 0.0018), while cutting speed alone is not (F = 1.32). Subgroup analysis shows tool geometry 1 favors high speed, while geometry 2 favors low speed. Therefore, the impact of speed depends on geometry.

question: An integrated circuit experiment tested furnace position and implant dose on resistivity. Assuming no interaction, perform ANOVA and conduct Tukey’s test.
solution: Implant dose is marginally significant (F = 18.08, p = 0.0511), while position is not (F = 1.15). Tukey’s test shows no significant differences among furnace positions. Thus, dose appears to influence resistivity more than position.

question: A coal sulfur content experiment tested two analysis methods across seven labs. Perform ANOVA to assess interaction and main effects.
solution: Interaction is not significant (F = 2.08, p = 0.1215). Both method (F = 6.57, p = 0.0226) and lab (F = 84.70, p < 0.0001) effects are significant. Method differences are lab-dependent, especially significant in lab 7 (p = 0.0093).

question: An algae growth experiment tested three copper levels and three times. Conduct ANOVA and comment on all effects.
solution: All three effects are significant: Time (F = 38.87), Copper (F = 13.58), and Interaction (F = 9.67), all with p < 0.001. Thus, algae growth depends on both factors and their interaction.

question: An EPA experiment tested two treatments and two time levels for magnesium uptake. Conduct ANOVA and regression analysis.
solution: Both main effects (treatment and time) are significant (F = 157.07 each, p < 0.0001), while interaction is not (F = 0.02, p = 0.8864). Regression confirms interaction is insignificant.

question: Using the data from Exercise 14.12, fit linear and quadratic regression models using copper and time as variables. Compare models.
solution: The linear model includes copper, time, and interaction, with all coefficients significant (R²_adj = 0.1788). The quadratic model fits better (R²_adj = 0.7700) and includes squared terms, all significant. Thus, the quadratic model is preferred.

question: A flame retardant study tested two baths and two laundering levels. Test for interaction and main effects using ANOVA.
solution: All effects are significant: Bath (F = 26.73), Laundering (F = 7.55), and Interaction (F = 6.21), all p < 0.05. Interaction shows the effect of laundering depends on the bath type.

question: A three-factor experiment involving A, B, and C tested a BC interaction. Test BC interaction and main effects.
solution: BC interaction has p = 0.0806, not significant at α = 0.05. After pooling with error, all main effects A, B, and C become significant (p-values: 0.0275, 0.0224, 0.0131).

question: An experiment tested three fixed factors A, B, and C. Test all main and interaction effects using ANOVA.
solution: Significant effects include B (p = 0.0030), AB (p = 0.0311), and AC (p = 0.0320). Interaction BC and ABC are not significant. A and C main effects are not significant due to masking by interaction.

question: An X-ray fluorescence experiment tested three factors A (4 levels), B (2), and C (2). Perform ANOVA and assess main and interaction effects.
solution: Significant effects: A (p = 0.0003), C (p < 0.0001), AB (p = 0.0185), BC (p = 0.0207). Interaction AC is marginal (p = 0.0931). B alone is not significant but may still matter due to interaction.

question: A corrosion fatigue experiment tested three factors: coating, humidity, and shear stress. Perform ANOVA and recommend factor levels to minimize damage.
solution: Significant interactions: Coating × Humidity (p = 0.0385), Humidity × Stress (p = 0.0192). Shear stress is a significant main effect. To minimize damage, use stress level 20, medium humidity, and uncoated surfaces.

question: A study tested three condensation methods and two gold types across five dentists. Evaluate interaction and main effects.
solution: Interaction between method and gold type is marginally significant (p = 0.10587). Method differences are significant only for Goldent (p = 0.0099), not for Gold Foil (p = 0.9801).

question: A copier quality experiment tested three factors: temperature, gluing roller surface, and press roller hardness. Perform ANOVA and assess main and interaction effects.
solution: Significant effects: A (p < 0.0001), B (p = 0.0020), AB (p = 0.0006), AC (p = 0.0369), BC (p = 0.0007), ABC (p = 0.0051). Only C alone is not significant. Multiple interactions are significant.

question: Using data from 14.21, plot significant two-way interactions and assess residuals.
solution: Interaction plots for Surface × Temp, Hardness × Temp, and Hardness × Surface all show clear interaction patterns. Normal Q-Q plot of residuals shows slight deviation from normality at the tails.

question: A laundry dirt removal experiment tested three detergent brands, two types, and two water temperatures. Perform ANOVA.
solution: All two-way interactions are significant (p < 0.0001). Main effect of brand is also significant. Optimal combination is brand Y, powder detergent, hot water.

question: A three-factor experiment tested powder temperature, extrusion rate, and die temperature on propellant radius. Perform ANOVA and plot interactions.
solution: All main effects are significant. Interactions AB and AC are not. Interaction plots show no clear two-way interaction. Thus, factor effects are additive.

question: A polyethylene gel extraction experiment tested solvent, temperature, and time. Perform ANOVA and plot significant interactions.
solution: Only the three-way interaction (Solvent × Temp × Time) is significant (p = 0.0140). All two-way interactions are not significant. Interaction plots confirm the effect depends on all three factors together.

question: Assume a random effects model for Exercise 14.2. Estimate the variance components for brand of orange juice concentrate, for number of days from blending, and for experimental error.
solution: The estimated variance components are: σ²_brand = 1.4678, σ²_time = 12.1642, and σ²_error = 0.9237. These were derived from the expected mean square equations for random effects models.

question: In a filtration process, the percent of material lost in the mother liquor was measured under 12 conditions. Perform ANOVA and estimate the variance components for filters, operators, and their interaction.
solution: ANOVA results show that both filters (F = 8.39, p = 0.0183) and operators (F = 12.45, p = 0.0055) have significant effects. The interaction (F = 1.49, p = 0.2229) is not significant. Estimated variance components are: σ²_filter = 0.17766, σ²_operator = 0.35158, σ²_error = 0.185.

question: A defense contractor studied inspection processes using three inspectors and three levels of inspection. Analyze interaction and main effects.
solution: The ANOVA showed that inspector effect (F = 0.02, p = 0.9806) and interaction (F = 0.04, p = 0.9973) were not significant. However, inspection level effect was significant (F = 54.77, p = 0.0012).

question: Given a random effects ANOVA summary table, test for significant variance components for all effects at the 0.01 level of significance using pooled and unpooled methods.
solution: Using pooled error estimates, significant components include B (f = 78.82), C (f = 13.54), and AC (f = 4.57). Using unpooled tests, only B, C, and AC remain significant. A, AB, BC, and ABC were not significant in either method.

question: A manager tested if fabric yield depends on operator or time of day using random effects. Analyze and estimate variance components.
solution: ANOVA showed negative variance estimates for both operator and time, indicating no significant effect from either. The yield appears consistent across all operators and times.

question: A paint manufacturer claims their product is more robust to material differences. Test the effects of paint brand and material on chipping time.
solution: Interaction is significant (F = 16.06, p = 0.0004). Brand main effect is not significant (F = 1.73, p = 0.2875). Brand A did not significantly outperform others across all materials.

question: Test whether power setting significantly affects cereal box weights using a mixed model with cereal type as a random effect.
solution: ANOVA results: power setting effect was not significant (F = 1.37, p = 0.3524), and variance component for cereal type was estimated to be negative. Thus, no significant effects were detected.

question: A cake study tested flour type and sweetener percentage on specific gravity. Use ANOVA to test main and interaction effects.
solution: Sweetener effect is nearly significant (F = 2.90, p = 0.0670), flour effect is not (F = 1.84), but interaction is significant (F = 3.38, p = 0.0442). All-purpose flour shows a strong decrease in gravity at 100% sweetener, while cake flour does not.

question: A texture study of fish in different sauces was conducted. Perform ANOVA to test for interaction and main effects.
solution: Sauce and fish type are both significant (p < 0.05). Interaction is not significant (F = 2.57, p = 0.0973). Therefore, both sauce and fish independently affect texture values.

question: Three plastic types were tested under four humidity levels to assess force needed to separate glued pieces. Analyze interaction.
solution: Interaction is significant (F = 5.29, p = 0.0070). Both main effects (plastic and humidity) are also significant. Thus, force required depends on both plastic type and humidity, and their combination.

question: A copper-nickel alloy experiment tested fatigue life under different environments and stress levels. Analyze for interaction and main effects.
solution: Interaction is not significant (F = 0.29, p = 0.7547). Both main effects—environment (F = 15.25) and stress (F = 360.94)—are significant. Fatigue life is affected by both factors, independently.

question: In the cake study from 14.33, cake volume was measured. Test for interaction and main effects.
solution: Interaction is not significant (F = 0.31). Sweetener is marginally significant (F = 2.65, p = 0.0843). Flour type is significant (F = 11.09, p = 0.0042). Thus, flour impacts volume more than sweetener concentration.

question: An engineer tested how three factors affect control valve sensitivity. Perform ANOVA.
solution: Only main effects A (F = 8.30, p = 0.0016) and B (F = 196.91, p < 0.0001) are significant. All interactions and factor C are not significant.

question: Using polyethylene extraction data, fit a regression model with solvent, temperature, time, and their interactions. Evaluate model appropriateness.
solution: Only temperature and time terms were significant in the regression model. None of the interactions were significant. Thus, the two solvents behave similarly apart from intercept differences.

question: A tire study examined turning radius across different air pressures and surfaces. Analyze for main and interaction effects.
solution: All main effects and interactions are not significant. None of the factors substantially affected turning radius.

question: A freeze-dried coffee flavor experiment tested three temperatures and four drying times. Perform ANOVA and provide a recommendation.
solution: Both main effects (time and temperature) are significant (p < 0.0001), and interaction is also significant (F = 4.68, p = 0.0111). The optimal combination is −20°C and 2 hours, balancing speed and flavor.

question: An urban bank recorded customers served by 4 tellers during 3 peak times. Analyze using ANOVA, considering Poisson assumptions.
solution: Standard ANOVA shows significant effects for Teller (F = 19.91, p < 0.0001) and Time (F = 10.08, p = 0.0003), but not interaction. Analysis with square-root transformation confirms same results. Normality is somewhat violated.

question: A study investigated the effects of flour type and sweetener percentage on cake attributes. Analyze for significant effects and interactions on specific gravity.
solution: ANOVA showed that the interaction between flour and sweetener was significant (p = 0.0442), even though the sweetener main effect was marginal (p = 0.0670) and flour was not significant (p = 0.1941). Specific gravity was significantly affected by sweetener concentration in all-purpose flour, but not in cake flour.

question: In a fish texture study, sauce and fish type were varied. Analyze ANOVA results for significant main effects and interaction.
solution: Both main effects (sauce: F = 7.32, p = 0.0123; fish: F = 58.58, p < 0.0001) were significant, but the interaction between sauce and fish type was not (F = 2.57, p = 0.0973). Thus, both factors independently affect texture.

question: A humidity and plastic type study tested force needed to separate glued plastics. Was there an interaction?
solution: Yes, interaction was significant (F = 5.29, p = 0.0070). Both humidity and plastic type also had significant main effects. The force required varied depending on both humidity level and plastic type combination.

question: An alloy fatigue life experiment tested stress and environment. Test for interaction and main effects.
solution: Interaction was not significant (F = 0.29, p = 0.7547), but both environment (F = 15.25, p = 0.0021) and stress (F = 360.94, p < 0.0001) were significant. Both independently affect fatigue life.

question: Test for interaction between sweetener and flour type on cake volume. Include analysis of main effects.
solution: Interaction effect was not significant (F = 0.31, p = 0.8209). Sweetener was marginal (F = 2.65, p = 0.0843), while flour was significant (F = 11.09, p = 0.0042). Cake flour produced higher volume.

question: Consider X1, X2, ..., Xn as independent Poisson random variables with parameters μ1, μ2, ..., μn. Use the properties of moment-generating functions to show that the sum of these variables is a Poisson random variable with mean and variance equal to the sum of the individual means.
solution: Let Y = X1 + X2 + ... + Xn. The moment-generating function of a Poisson variable with mean μ is M_X(t) = e^(μ(e^t−1)). Applying this to each Xi, the moment-generating function of Y is the product of individual MGFs: M_Y(t) = e^(μ1(e^t−1)) · e^(μ2(e^t−1)) · ... · e^(μn(e^t−1)) = e^((μ1+μ2+...+μn)(e^t−1)). This is the MGF of a Poisson distribution with mean and variance equal to the sum of the μi values.

question: A quality control chart is to be created for defects per steel plate. Based on the provided sample data, construct the control chart and assess if the process is in control.
solution: Using a Poisson model, the estimated defect rate is λ̂ = 2.4. The control limits are LCL = −2.25 and UCL = 7.048. All data fall within these bounds, indicating the process is in control.

question: Estimate the proportion of defectives being produced by the machine in Example 18.1 if the random sample of size 2 yields 2 defectives.
solution: The probabilities of observing 2 defectives under p = 0.1 and p = 0.2 are calculated. Using Bayes' theorem with prior probabilities 0.6 for p = 0.1 and 0.4 for p = 0.2, the posterior probabilities are computed as 0.27 for p = 0.1 and 0.73 for p = 0.2. The Bayes estimate is then the weighted average: 0.1 × 0.27 + 0.2 × 0.73 = 0.173.

question: Given the prior distribution for the proportion p of drinks from a vending machine that overflow: p = 0.05 with probability 0.3, p = 0.10 with probability 0.5, and p = 0.15 with probability 0.2. If 2 of the next 9 drinks overflow, find (a) the posterior distribution for p; (b) the Bayes estimate of p.
solution: (a) The posterior probabilities are computed using binomial likelihoods and Bayes’ theorem: π(p=0.05|x=2)=0.12, π(p=0.10|x=2)=0.55, π(p=0.15|x=2)=0.33. (b) The Bayes estimate is the expected value: 0.05×0.12 + 0.10×0.55 + 0.15×0.33 = 0.111.

question: Repeat Exercise 18.2 when 1 of the next 4 drinks overflows and the prior distribution is uniform: π(p) = 10 for 0.05 < p < 0.15.
solution: The posterior distribution is proportional to 40p(1-p)^3, normalized over the interval (0.05, 0.15). The Bayes estimator is computed as the expected value of p under this posterior, yielding p* = 0.106.

question: Service calls arrive at a maintenance center according to a Poisson process with rate λ. A sample of 20 one-minute intervals shows an average of 1.8 calls. If the prior for λ is exponential with mean 2, find the posterior distribution of λ.
solution: The posterior distribution is obtained by multiplying the Poisson likelihood and exponential prior. This results in a gamma distribution with shape 37 and rate approximately 20.5, or λ ∼ gamma(37, 0.04878).

question: A prior beta distribution with mean 70% and standard deviation 10% is assumed for the proportion p of chain smokers with lung cancer. A new sample shows 81 out of 120 chain smokers have lung cancer. (a) Determine the posterior distribution. (b) What is the probability that p > 50%?
solution: (a) Solving for the beta prior parameters yields α = 14 and β = 6. The posterior is then beta(95, 45). (b) Using numerical methods, the probability that p > 0.5 is approximately 1.

question: A developer claims 3 out of 5 buyers prefer two-bedroom units, while a banker claims 7 out of 10. The banker is twice as reliable. If 12 of the next 15 units sold are two-bedroom, find (a) the posterior probabilities; (b) the Bayes estimate.
solution: (a) Using binomial probabilities and prior weights (1/3 for developer, 2/3 for banker), the posterior probabilities are 0.157 for p=0.6 and 0.843 for p=0.7. (b) The Bayes estimate is the weighted average: 0.6×0.157 + 0.7×0.843 = 0.614.

question: Burn time for a rocket's first stage is normal with σ = 0.8. Prior for μ is normal with mean 8 and σ = 0.2. If the mean burn time for 10 rockets is 9 minutes, find a 95% Bayesian interval for μ.
solution: Using the formulas for Bayesian updating of normal distributions, the posterior mean is 8.3846 and the posterior standard deviation is 0.1569. A 95% interval is 8.3846 ± 1.96×0.1569, yielding (8.0771, 8.6921).

question: Daily profit from a juice vending machine is normally distributed with unknown mean μ and known variance. The prior for μ is N(30, 1.75^2). For one machine, a 30-day sample yields x̄ = 24.90, s = 2.10. Find (a) the Bayes estimate of μ; (b) a 95% Bayesian interval; (c) the probability μ is between $24.00 and $26.00.
solution: (a) Using conjugate normal updates, the Bayes estimate is 25.1336. (b) The 95% interval is 25.1336 ± 1.96×0.3745 = (23.40, 25.86). (c) Standardizing, P(24 < μ < 26) ≈ 0.9885.

question: A placement test has average score modeled as N(72, 5.76). (a) What is the prior probability that the average falls between 71.8 and 73.4? (b) A sample of 100 students has x̄ = 70 and variance = 64. Find a 95% Bayesian interval. (c) What is the posterior probability for part (a)?
solution: (a) Using the normal CDF, the prior probability is approximately 0.2534. (b) After Bayesian updating, the posterior mean is 70.2 and standard deviation is 0.759. The interval is (68.71, 71.69). (c) Using the updated distribution, P(71.8 < μ < 73.4) ≈ 0.0174.

question: The electrical firm assumes μ is between 770 and 830, with prior π(μ) = 1/60. A sample of 25 bulbs gives an average of 780 hours. Find the posterior distribution.
solution: Combining the likelihood and uniform prior, the posterior distribution of μ is a truncated normal with mean 780 and standard deviation 20, truncated to (770, 830).

question: Time to failure T is exponential with rate θ. Prior for θ is exponential with rate 2. Given n observations, show that the posterior is gamma with parameters α = n + 1, β = 1 / (sum of ti + 2).
solution: By multiplying the likelihood and prior and simplifying, the posterior distribution of θ is shown to be a gamma distribution with shape α = n+1 and rate β = 1 / (∑ti + 2).

question: A sample of 10 Poisson values: 5, 6, 6, 7, 5, 6, 4, 9, 3, and 6. The prior for λ is gamma(3,2). Find the Bayes estimate under squared-error loss.
solution: The sample sum is 57, n = 10. Posterior is gamma(60, 1/10.5). The Bayes estimate is the posterior mean: λ* = 60 / 10.5 ≈ 5.7143.

question: X follows a negative binomial distribution with k = 5 and unknown p, with a uniform prior on (0, 1). Find the Bayes estimate of p under squared-error loss.
solution: The posterior distribution is beta(6, x−4), and the Bayes estimator is the mean of this beta distribution: p* = 6 / (x + 2).

question: X follows an exponential distribution with mean 1/β. The prior for β is exponential with mean 2.5. Find the Bayes estimate under absolute-error loss.
solution: Combining likelihood and prior, the posterior is exponential with mean 5/7. The median is computed by solving 0.5 = 1 − e^(−(7/5)β), giving β̂ = 0.495.

question: A sample of 20 values from U(0, θ) with prior π(θ) = 1 / θ² for θ > 1. Given the data, determine the Bayes estimator under absolute-error loss.
solution: The posterior distribution is proportional to 1 / θ² for θ > max(x) = 2.14. The normalized posterior yields a median (Bayes estimator) of θ = 2.21.
